qas.question: What is the sea life reserve named at St. Barts?
How many hectares does the marine preserve cover?
What general species of animal was the marine reserve designed to protect?
What is prohibited in all zones of the marine reserve at St. Barts?
Colombier Bay has what type of helpful structures placed in the water?
Besides Colombier what other bay has mooring buoys?
How big is each of the 5 zones that make up the Reserve Naturelle?
In what bay were the first mooring buoys installed?

context: Saint-Barthélemy has a marine nature reserve, known as the <a0_0>Reserve Naturelle<a0_0/> that covers <a1_0><b5_0><b7_0>1.200<a1_0/> ha<b7_0/><b5_0/>, and is divided into 5 zones all around the island to form a network of protected areas. The Reserve includes the bays of <b6_0>Grand Cul de Sac<b6_0/>, Colombier, Marigot, Petit Cul de Sac, <b8_0>Petite Anse<b8_0/> as well as waters around offshore rocks such as Les Gross Islets, Pain de Sucre, Tortue and Forchue. The Reserve is designed to protect the islands coral reefs, seagrass and endangered marine species including <a2_0>sea turtles<a2_0/>. The Reserve has two levels of protection, the yellow zones of protection where certain non-extractive activities, like snorkeling and boating, are allowed and the red zones of high protection where most activities including SCUBA are restricted in order to protect or recover marine life. <a3_0>Anchoring<a3_0/> is prohibited in the Reserve and <a4_0>mooring buoys<a4_0/> are in place in some of the protected bays like Colombier
